handNote.p: The scribe Hemming. One of three main hands active in this homily. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule with a slightly more rectangular aspect. The hand is distinguished by the 'running-man' shape of the eth's crossing stroke, with the left terminal curling up and the right terminal curling down. The ascender of eth is also usually a straight diagonal, rather than curving.
One of three main hands active in this homily. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule with a rounder aspect.
One of three main hands active in this homily. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule with letterforms very similar to Hemming's (ECHOE HandID DP1056) but a less regular aspect and a clumsier appearance.

An addending hand generally using a somewhat more finely-cut pen. The hand is marked by its tendency to leave a small gap at the top of e and fondness for an upwardly-curling long tongue on e. This hand sometimes adds interlinear Latin glosses or 'vel'-alternatives in other homilies. The same hand can be seen in other places in Hatton 113 and Hatton 114, generally inserting words either by extending the descender of a letter downward to mark the intended insertion area, or using a double-punctus marking. This is the same hand as that identified by ECHOE handIDs DP1032a and DP1036a.
